facts.text: The respondent, Dharampur Leather Company Ltd., Bombay, was incorporated on June 15, 1943, as a private limited company.

facts.text: Dharampur State merged with the Province of Bombay on August 1, 1949.

facts.text: Promoters secured total exemption from State Income Tax from the Ruler of Dharampur for seven years from commencement of working.

anchor.surface_text: Para 15 of the said order provides as follows 15 1  Where any industrial undertaking situate in a merged State claims that it has been granted any exemption from or concession in respect of income-, super-tax or business profits tax by the Ruler of the State before the 1st day of August, 1949, it shall submit an application to the Commissioner of Income- tax giving the following particulars - Name of the Industrial undertaking. Status  i.e. whether public or private company, firm, individual or Hindu undivided family . Nature of business. Date of commencement of the business. Nature of the concessions granted. Period for which concessions granted. Unexpired period of the concessions from the 1st day of August, 1949. The application shall be accompanied by a copy of the orders of the State granting the concession or of the agreement with the State. The Commissioner shall, after obtaining such other information as he may require, forward the application to the Central Government which, having regard to all the circumstances of the case, may grant such relief, if any, as it thinks appropriate.

concepts.interpretation: Provides procedure for claiming exemption granted by Ruler post-merger; Central Govt may grant relief

holdings.text: The words 'actually allowed' occurring in s. 10(5)(b) of the Act must be interpreted to exclude any notional allowance, following the interpretation in para 2 of the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949

anchor.surface_text: There is no force in this contention. We have delivered judgment today in Commissioner of Income Tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Messrs Straw Products Limited Bhopal 1 and held that the words actually allowed in para 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, did not include any notional allowance. Following that judgment, we must interpret the words actually allowed occurring in s. 10 5   b  of the Act in the same manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects contention that depreciation deemed allowed in exempted years; follows concurrent judgment in CIT v. Straw Products holding 'actually allowed' excludes notional allowance in analogous provision and applies same to s.10(5)(b)

holdings.text: The Explanation inserted by the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties (Amendment) Order, 1962 has no bearing on the facts of this case

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this contention. In our opinion, the Explanation inserted by 1962 Order has no bearing on the facts of this ,case. The exemption granted by the Central Government is granted under para 15 of the Merged States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1949,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption granted by Central Government under para 15 of Merged States Taxation Concessions Order, 1949 issued under s.60A of the Act, constituting grant under the Act and not under any agreement with Ruler

holdings.text: The exemption was granted under the Act and not under any agreement

anchor.surface_text: The exemption granted by the Central Government is granted under para 15 of the Merged States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1949, which was itself issued under s. 60A of the Act. The result is that the exemption was granted under the Act and not under any agreement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 15 of 1949 Order issued under s.60A empowers Central Government to grant relief, distinct from agreements with Rulers

anchor.surface_text: The exemption granted by the Central Government is granted under para 15 of the Merged States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1949, which was itself issued under s. 60A of the Act. The result is that the exemption was granted under the Act and not under any agreement.

There is no force in this contention. We have delivered judgment today in Commissioner of Income Tax, Madhya Pradesh v. Messrs Straw Products Limited Bhopal 1 and held that the words actually allowed in para 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, did number include any numberional allowance.
